ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of intellectual challenge of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the workload of this course was:

narratives.question_text: What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
comments: How to write a history thesis: mastery of secondary literature, searching/analyzing primary sources, writing a paper of such considerable length.
How to write a history thesis!
A deep understanding of African political ideology as defined by Senghor and Nkrumah.
I learned a lot through completing my thesis, not a real class but a valuable experience nonetheless.
I was able to work on a year-long passion project, conduct archival research, and synthesize it all into a 50 page thesis.

narratives.question_text: What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
comments: I do think the history department could provide a few more resources about how to approach the senior essay. I was lucky to have a wonderful advisor, but many of my friends were not so lucky and felt a lack of guidance/direction. I also think the benchmark assignments could be switched with more pragmatic assignments to optimize efficiency/streamline success.
It is what you make of it.

narratives.question_text: Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
comments: Um yeah? If you want a degree?

Absolutely write a senior essay if you have a chance to do so. The intellectual challenge combined with the opportunity to become close with an advisor is an opportunity that won't be mirrored with any other class you take at Yale.
